function.name: puppeteer_puppeteer_evaluate

content.text:
Execution result:
"The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Srinivas Mohan. Enthiran emerged as the highest-grossing Indian film of 2010. It won two National Film Awards, three Filmfare Awards, seven Vijay Awards and two Screen Awards. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.

The Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]

Enthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the "best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film" and that it was "one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made."[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it "the perfect getaway film".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, "Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]

Both Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. Chopra criticised the film's portions in the second half, describing them as "needlessly stretched and cacophonous", but concluded her review by saying, "Robot rides on Rajinikanth's shoulders and he never stoops under the burden. Aided by snazzy clothes, make-up and special effects, he makes Chitti endearing."[168] Srinivasan, however, said that Shankar "strikes the balance between science fiction and masala quotient." She concluded that, "Whichever way you look at it, Endhiran [sic] is one of those rare films that give you just enough material to pull you in, and enjoy yourself."[169] Rajeev Masand of News18 gave a rating of three out of five stars and said, "In the end, it's the fantastic special effects and an inspired performance from Rajnikant [sic] that keeps the film fresh."[170]"

content.text:
Execution result:
"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450 million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60 million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

"The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Srinivas Mohan. Enthiran emerged as the highest-grossing Indian film of 2010. It won two National Film Awards, three Filmfare Awards, seven Vijay Awards and two Screen Awards. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]\n\nEnthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the \"best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film\" and that it was \"one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made.\"[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. Chopra criticised the film's portions in the second half, describing them as \"needlessly stretched and cacophonous\", but concluded her review by saying, \"Robot rides on Rajinikanth's shoulders and he never stoops under the burden. Aided by snazzy clothes, make-up and special effects, he makes Chitti endearing.\"[168] Srinivasan, however, said that Shankar \"strikes the balance between science fiction and masala quotient.\" She concluded that, \"Whichever way you look at it, Endhiran [sic] is one of those rare films that give you just enough material to pull you in, and enjoy yourself.\"[169] Rajeev Masand of News18 gave a rating of three out of five stars and said, \"In the end, it's the fantastic special effects and an inspired performance from Rajnikant [sic] that keeps the film fresh.\"[170]"

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

- She was paid ₹60 million for her role.
- Her voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.

There is no detailed critique of her performance in the extracted text, but it highlights her significant role and involvement in the film's production and release events.

If you want, I can look further or try to find more detailed reviews specifically about her performance.

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]\n\nEnthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the \"best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film\" and that it was \"one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made.\"[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. Chopra criticised the film's portions in the second half, describing them as \"needlessly stretched and cacophonous\", but concluded her review by saying, \"Robot rides on Rajinikanth's shoulders and he never stoops under the burden. "Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. "Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. "The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Srinivas Mohan. Enthiran emerged as the highest-grossing Indian film of 2010. It won two National Film Awards, three Filmfare Awards, seven Vijay Awards and two Screen Awards. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]\n\nEnthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the \"best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film\" and that it was \"one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made.\"[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. Chopra criticised the film's portions in the second half, describing them as \"needlessly stretched and cacophonous\", but concluded her review by saying, \"Robot rides on Rajinikanth's shoulders and he never stoops under the burden. Aided by snazzy clothes, make-up and special effects, he makes Chitti endearing.\"[168] Srinivasan, however, said that Shankar \"strikes the balance between science fiction and masala quotient.\" She concluded that, \"Whichever way you look at it, Endhiran [sic] is one of those rare films that give you just enough material to pull you in, and enjoy yourself.\"[169] Rajeev Masand of News18 gave a rating of three out of five stars and said, \"In the end, it's the fantastic special effects and an inspired performance from Rajnikant [sic] that keeps the film fresh.\"[170]"

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. "The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Srinivas Mohan. Enthiran emerged as the highest-grossing Indian film of 2010. It won two National Film Awards, three Filmfare Awards, seven Vijay Awards and two Screen Awards. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]\n\nEnthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the \"best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film\" and that it was \"one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made.\"[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. "Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

"The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Srinivas Mohan. Enthiran emerged as the highest-grossing Indian film of 2010. It won two National Film Awards, three Filmfare Awards, seven Vijay Awards and two Screen Awards. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]\n\nEnthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the \"best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film\" and that it was \"one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made.\"[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. Chopra criticised the film's portions in the second half, describing them as \"needlessly stretched and cacophonous\", but concluded her review by saying, \"Robot rides on Rajinikanth's shoulders and he never stoops under the burden. Aided by snazzy clothes, make-up and special effects, he makes Chitti endearing.\"[168] Srinivasan, however, said that Shankar \"strikes the balance between science fiction and masala quotient.\" She concluded that, \"Whichever way you look at it, Endhiran [sic] is one of those rare films that give you just enough material to pull you in, and enjoy yourself.\"[169] Rajeev Masand of News18 gave a rating of three out of five stars and said, \"In the end, it's the fantastic special effects and an inspired performance from Rajnikant [sic] that keeps the film fresh.\"[170]"

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

"The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Srinivas Mohan. Enthiran emerged as the highest-grossing Indian film of 2010. It won two National Film Awards, three Filmfare Awards, seven Vijay Awards and two Screen Awards. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]\n\nEnthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the \"best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film\" and that it was \"one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made.\"[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. Chopra criticised the film's portions in the second half, describing them as \"needlessly stretched and cacophonous\", but concluded her review by saying, \"Robot rides on Rajinikanth's shoulders and he never stoops under the burden. Aided by snazzy clothes, make-up and special effects, he makes Chitti endearing.\"[168] Srinivasan, however, said that Shankar \"strikes the balance between science fiction and masala quotient.\" She concluded that, \"Whichever way you look at it, Endhiran [sic] is one of those rare films that give you just enough material to pull you in, and enjoy yourself.\"[169] Rajeev Masand of News18 gave a rating of three out of five stars and said, \"In the end, it's the fantastic special effects and an inspired performance from Rajnikant [sic] that keeps the film fresh.\"[170]"

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

"The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. "Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

"The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Srinivas Mohan. Enthiran emerged as the highest-grossing Indian film of 2010. It won two National Film Awards, three Filmfare Awards, seven Vijay Awards and two Screen Awards. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]\n\nEnthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the \"best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film\" and that it was \"one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made.\"[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. Chopra criticised the film's portions in the second half, describing them as \"needlessly stretched and cacophonous\", but concluded her review by saying, \"Robot rides on Rajinikanth's shoulders and he never stoops under the burden. Aided by snazzy clothes, make-up and special effects, he makes Chitti endearing.\"[168] Srinivasan, however, said that Shankar \"strikes the balance between science fiction and masala quotient.\" She concluded that, \"Whichever way you look at it, Endhiran [sic] is one of those rare films that give you just enough material to pull you in, and enjoy yourself.\"[169] Rajeev Masand of News18 gave a rating of three out of five stars and said, \"In the end, it's the fantastic special effects and an inspired performance from Rajnikant [sic] that keeps the film fresh.\"[170]"

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. "The film received generally positive reviews upon release, with critics being particularly appreciative of Shankar's direction, storyline, Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti, music, action sequences, production values and the visual effects by V. Srinivas Mohan. Enthiran emerged as the highest-grossing Indian film of 2010. It won two National Film Awards, three Filmfare Awards, seven Vijay Awards and two Screen Awards. Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]\n\nEnthiran received positive reviews from critics in India, with praise particularly directed at Rathnavelu's cinematography, Cyril's art direction, Srinivas Mohan's visual effects and Rajinikanth's performance as Chitti.[162][163] Aniruddha Guha of Daily News and Analysis gave the film a rating of four out of five stars and believed it had the \"best special effects ever seen in a Tamil film\" and that it was \"one of the most entertaining Tamil films—across all languages—ever made.\"[164] Both Nikhat Kazmi of The Times of India and Kaveree Bamzai of India Today rated the film four out of five stars. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. Chopra criticised the film's portions in the second half, describing them as \"needlessly stretched and cacophonous\", but concluded her review by saying, \"Robot rides on Rajinikanth's shoulders and he never stoops under the burden. Aided by snazzy clothes, make-up and special effects, he makes Chitti endearing.\"[168] Srinivasan, however, said that Shankar \"strikes the balance between science fiction and masala quotient.\" She concluded that, \"Whichever way you look at it, Endhiran [sic] is one of those rare films that give you just enough material to pull you in, and enjoy yourself.\"[169] Rajeev Masand of News18 gave a rating of three out of five stars and said, \"In the end, it's the fantastic special effects and an inspired performance from Rajnikant [sic] that keeps the film fresh.\"[170]"

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

"Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"

Enthiran was followed by a standalone sequel, 2.0, which released in late 2018.\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Kazmi called it \"the perfect getaway film\".[165] Bamzai praised Rajinikanth's acting in the film and said, \"Rajni tells us why robot sapiens are superior to homo sapiens\".[166] Cable Shankar of Kalki magazine praised the technical aspects, music, stunts and direction while calling Chitti's character attracts more attention than Vaseegaran. He also stated that first half was interesting using Chitti's character but the second half had uninteresting sequences which proves to be a obstacle to the screenplay yet they manage to compensate with graphics in the film's climax and concluded saying little bit of science fiction + usual emotions + many Rajinis + logic = Enthiran.[167]\n\nBoth Anupama Chopra of NDTV and Pavithra Srinivasan of Rediff.com gave Enthiran a rating of three-and-a-half stars out of five. "Enthiran (transl. Robot) is a 2010 Indian Tamil-language science fiction action film co-written and directed by S. Shankar.[12] It is the first instalment in the Enthiran film series. The film stars Rajinikanth in dual lead roles as a scientist and the robot he created, respectively. Aishwarya Rai Bachchan, Danny Denzongpa, Santhanam and Karunas play supporting roles. The soundtrack album and background score were composed by A. R. Rahman while the dialogues, cinematography, editing and art direction were handled by Madhan Karky, R. Rathnavelu, Anthony and Sabu Cyril and action sequences was done by Peter Hein respectively. The story revolves around the struggle of a scientist named Vaseegaran to control his sophisticated android robot named Chitti, after Chitti's software is upgraded to give it the ability to comprehend and exhibit human emotions and to commission it to the Indian Army. The project backfires when Chitti falls in love with Vaseegaran's girlfriend Sana, and is manipulated by Vaseegaran's mentor Bohra into becoming homicidal.\n\nIn January 2008, Rajinikanth accepted the lead role in the film for a salary of ₹450\xa0million (Indian rupees).[33][37][Note 3][13] Shankar rewrote the original script to suit Rajinikanth's acting style.[13] Although Aishwarya Rai Bachchan was Shankar's original choice for the female lead in 2001, she declined it owing to a busy schedule and was replaced by Zinta.[39] When Shankar revived the project with Rajinikanth,[33] contenders for the part included Deepika Padukone,[40] Shriya Saran and Rai, who was ultimately selected and paid ₹60\xa0million.[41][42][Note 3] Rai's voice was dubbed by Savitha Reddy.[43][Note 4]\n\nThe Tamil album was officially released on 31 July 2010 with a promotional event held at the Putrajaya International Convention Centre in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.[108] Co-hosted by Vivek and Punnagai Poo Gheetha, the event was attended by most of the film's cast and crew members. Other invited guests were Dayanidhi Maran, Radha Ravi, Vadivelu, Shriya Saran, Jayam Ravi, Ramya Krishnan, S. A. Chandrasekhar, Aishwarya and Soundarya Rajinikanth, Krish, and Sangeetha Arvind. Furthermore, Silambarasan, Vijayalakshmi, and Poorna were part of stage performances. The release event of the Telugu version, titled Robo, was held in Hyderabad on 6 August 2010, which was attended by Chiranjeevi, D. Ramanaidu, Mohan Babu, Srinu Vaitla, Kajal Aggarwal, and Kamna Jethmalani.[115] The Hindi version, titled Robot, was released by Venus[116] on 14 August 2010, in a function held in Mumbai. The event was attended by Amitabh Bachchan, Jaya Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan, along with the crew of the film.[117]"
